title: 107_s1733
content: The Act titled "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" establishes an interoperable law enforcement and intelligence data system with name matching capacity and training. The Act "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" mandates the development of a unified electronic data system by key government agencies to facilitate visa issuance and alien admissibility determinations. The system must have name matching capacity across different databases. The unified electronic data system required by the "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" must have the capacity to match names across different databases, be searchable on a linguistically sensitive basis, provide user support, be developed in consultation with private sector firms, utilize commercially available platforms, and be continuously adjusted and improved based on experience and technological advancements. The unified electronic database required by the "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" must be searchable using linguistically sensitive algorithms that account for variations in name formats and transliterations within a particular language. Linguistically sensitive algorithms must account for variations in name formats and transliterations within specific languages, incorporating advanced research methods. These algorithms should be developed for at least 4 high-priority languages designated by key government officials. Adequate user support is also required. Algorithms must be developed for at least 4 high-priority languages designated by key government officials. The unified electronic data system should provide easily accessed information about names in different languages and a means for communication with experts. Interim reports are required every 6 months. The Act requires the development of algorithms for high-priority languages, a unified electronic data system for name information, and a means for communication with experts. Interim reports must be submitted every 6 months, and intelligence agencies must adhere to current standards within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Director of Central Intelligence must complete a survey and issue a report within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Director of Intelligence must issue guidelines and submit a copy within 120 days. The Director of Intelligence must issue guidelines within 120 days of the Act's enactment. Consultation is required with various government agencies and entities in developing and implementing the data system. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out the provisions of this subsection. The Director of Intelligence must issue guidelines for the data system within 120 days of the Act's enactment. Consultation with government agencies is required for development and implementation. The data system will utilize a technology standard established by the USA PATRIOT Act. Access to information in the system will be available to Foreign Service officers and Federal agents. The Obstruct Terrorism Act of 2001 establishes a data system with accessible information for Foreign Service officers and Federal agents. Procedures are in place to restrict access to intelligence information in certain circumstances.
